Course Description: PRESENTS CONCEPTS AND TERMINOLOGY OF ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEMS AND THEIR USE IN ACCOUNTING AND AUDITING DECISION MAKING.  TOPICS ALSO INCLUDE INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY FUNDAMENTALS, RESPONSIBILITIES AND BUSINESS IMPLICATIONS.
Objectives / Learning Outcome(s) / Major:
UPON COMPLETION OF THIS COURSE, STUDENTS ARE ABLE TO:
1.EXPLAIN THE BASIC ROLE INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY PLAYS IN A BUSINESS ENVIRONMENT
2.DESCRIBE THE ROLE AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF AN INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY DEPARTMENT
3.DESCRIBE BASIC INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY FUNDAMENTALS SUCH AS HARDWARE, SOFTWARE, SYSTEM OPERATIONS AND DISASTER RECOVERY
4.IDENTIFY FINANCIAL STATEMENT AND BUSINESS IMPLICATIONS OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY
5.IMPROVE RESEARCH, ORAL AND WRITTEN COMMUNICATION SKILLS
6.DISCUSS PRINCIPLES OF ETHICAL AND PROFESSIONAL BUSINESS CONDUCT
Textbook(s):
ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEMS A BUSINESS PROCESS APPROACH, 2ND EDITION
THOMSON-SOUTH-WESTERN
JONES AND RAMA
ISBN 0-324-301618
Transfer Status: GUARANTEED TRANSFER TO INSTITUTION OFFERING SAME COURSE.
